sync.title: Sync & CRDT System
sync.subtitle: Deep dive into how haex-vault synchronizes data across devices using Column-Level CRDTs and Hybrid Logical Clocks.

overview.title: Sync Overview
overview.intro: haex-vault uses a CRDT (Conflict-free Replicated Data Type) based sync system that enables seamless offline-first operation with automatic conflict resolution.

offline.title: Offline-First
offline.description: Work without internet. Changes sync when you're back online.

realtime.title: Realtime Sync
realtime.description: Supabase Realtime pushes updates instantly to other devices.

e2e.title: E2E Encrypted
e2e.description: All synced data is encrypted before leaving your device.

crdtBasics.title: CRDT Fundamentals
crdtBasics.intro: CRDTs are data structures that can be replicated across multiple computers, modified independently, and merged without conflicts.

lww.title: Last-Write-Wins (LWW)
lww.description: haex-vault uses LWW semantics with Hybrid Logical Clocks. The change with the highest timestamp always wins, ensuring deterministic conflict resolution across all devices.

columns.title: CRDT Columns
columns.description: Every synced table has three special columns that enable CRDT functionality:
columns.comment: All synced tables have these columns
columns.timestamp: Max HLC across all columns (for efficient queries)
columns.columnHlcs: JSON object with HLC per column

hlc.title: Hybrid Logical Clocks
hlc.intro: HLCs combine physical time with logical counters to create globally unique, monotonically increasing timestamps without requiring synchronized clocks.
hlc.format: HLC Format: ISO 8601 timestamp + Device ID suffix
hlc.benefit1: Lexicographically sortable - can use simple string comparison
hlc.benefit2: Globally unique - device ID suffix prevents collisions

columnLevel.title: Column-Level Sync
columnLevel.intro: Unlike row-level sync, haex-vault tracks changes at the column level. This means concurrent edits to different columns of the same row are automatically merged without data loss.

example.title: Conflict Resolution Example
example.code:
Device A: UPDATE passwords SET title = 'Gmail' WHERE id = 'abc'
         (timestamp: 2024-01-03T10:00:00-A)

Device B: UPDATE passwords SET password = 'newpass' WHERE id = 'abc'
         (timestamp: 2024-01-03T10:00:15-B)

Result after sync:
- title = 'Gmail'     (from Device A)
- password = 'newpass' (from Device B)

Both changes are preserved!

important.title: No Data Loss
important.description: With column-level tracking, two devices can edit different fields of the same record simultaneously, and both changes will be preserved.

syncFlow.title: Sync Flow
syncFlow.intro: The sync process involves three main operations: push, pull, and realtime subscriptions.

push.title: Push Operation
push.description: When you make changes locally, the sync orchestrator detects dirty tables, scans for changes since the last push, encrypts each value, and sends them to the server in batches.

pull.title: Pull Operation
pull.description: Pull fetches changes from the server since the last pull timestamp. Each change is decrypted and compared against local data using HLC timestamps. Only newer changes are applied.

realtime.title: Realtime Updates
realtime.intro: haex-vault subscribes to Supabase Realtime channels to receive instant notifications when other devices push changes. This triggers a debounced pull operation.

fallback.title: Fallback Polling
fallback.description: If realtime subscriptions fail, the system falls back to periodic polling (every 5 minutes) to ensure data stays synchronized.

softDelete.title: Soft Delete with Tombstones
softDelete.intro: haex-vault uses soft deletion instead of actual DELETE statements. This ensures deletes can be properly synchronized across devices.
softDelete.why: Soft deletion allows the delete operation to be treated like any other column change, syncing properly through the CRDT system. The row remains in the database with haex_tombstone = 1.

events.title: Sync Events
events.intro: After a successful pull, events are emitted to notify the application that data has changed. This triggers UI updates and store reloads.

twoEvents.title: Two Event Types
twoEvents.internal: For internal Pinia stores (registered via registerStoreForTables)

important.title: Both Events Required
important.description: When implementing sync, ensure BOTH events are emitted so that both internal stores and extensions receive updates.
